docs.lead_paragraph: Congress is trying to push through unfair, damaging tax provisions by attaching them to two popular bills, one designed to raise the minimum wage, the other to protect patients in managed care. The bills have passed both Senate and House and are headed for conference. None of the tax provisions deserve to survive. As part of the patients' bill of rights legislation for managed-care plans, the Republicans attached a provision to create a universal right to put tax-free money into medical savings accounts. Individuals would first have to purchase a high-deductible insurance policy that would cover medical bills only after they exceed a large annual amount, say $3,000. The tax-free medical savings account would cover the costs under $3,000.

headline.main: Bad Tax Cuts Inside Good Bills

docs.abstract: Editorial scores Congressional efforts to create universal right to put tax-free money into medical savings accounts and to raise amounts highly paid workers can put into tax-deductible pension accounts by attaching unfair measures to popular bills
docs.snippet: Congress is trying to push through unfair, damaging tax provisions by attaching them to two popular bills, one designed to raise the minimum wage, the other to protect patients in managed care. The bills have passed both Senate and House and are...

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the nation's largest managed-care insurer, settled a lawsuit in Texas yesterday by agreeing to change several practices that doctors and consumer advocates portrayed as undermining patient care, like rewarding physicians who stayed within cost limits. Aetna said it was ready to make similar changes in other states, but officials in New York and Connecticut said that, on first look, the Texas concessions were not far-reaching enough to satisfy their concerns.

headline.main: Aetna Settles Texas Suit Over Doctors' Cost Rules

docs.abstract: Aetna, nation's largest managed-care insurer, settles lawsuit in Texas by agreeing to change several practices that doctors and consumer advocates portrayed as undermining patient care, like rewarding physicians who stayed within cost limits; Aetna says it is ready to make similar changes in other states, but officials in New York and Connecticut say that, on first look, Texas concessions are not far-reaching enough to satisfy their concerns; changes are first since company's new chief executive, William H Donaldson, pledged last month to improve Aetna US Healthcare's relations with doctors; John Cornyn, attorney general of Texas, says agreement will curtail financial incentives that 'tempt doctors to deny necessary medical care' by linking physicians' incomes to holding down costs; Aetna says it will stop paying set amount for each health-plan member to doctors whose practices have fewer than 100 health maintenance organization members; instead, they will be paid a fee for each service; doctors with more than 100 HMO members will continue to be paid per member; Cornyn says he hopes settlement will be precedent for settling other lawsuits against insurance companies like Humana Inc, Pacficare and NYLcare unit that Aetna was forced to sell to Texas Blue Cross and Blue Shield; officials of American Medical Association and Texas Medical Association say agreement is step in right direction, but they say it shows need for national patients' rights legislation that would remove obstacles to medical malpractice lawsuits against insurers (M)
docs.snippet: Aetna, the nation's largest managed-care insurer, settled a lawsuit in Texas yesterday by agreeing to change several practices that doctors and consumer advocates portrayed as undermining patient care, like rewarding physicians who stayed within cost...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I was struck by Dr. Edward Flaschner's tale of the two doctors' offices -- Dr. Harried and Dr. Relaxed (letter, April 11) -- and his assertion that doctors' interests and those of their patients pretty well mesh. I am definitely seeing the relaxed doctor. I get excellent regular care for a chronic condition. He asks concerned questions, writes out a prescription (this takes no more than 15 minutes), and he charges $150, roughly $10 a minute. It is the going rate, and I can afford it. I like him; I'm not really complaining. If he's not Marcus Welby, he's close.
docs.abstract: Tessa Joseph letter comments on Dr Edward Flaschner's April 11 letter asserting that doctors' interests and those of their patients pretty well mesh

docs.lead_paragraph: Fleshing out his frequent pledge to remove ''obstacles on the road to the middle class,'' Gov. George W. Bush entered the national debate over health care policy today by proposing a tax credit of up to $2,000 a family to help low- and moderate-income working people buy health insurance. The credit, worth $34.7 billion over five years, was the most costly of an array of proposed tax incentives and vouchers for health care and home ownership that Mr. Bush packaged today as ''a new prosperity initiative'' intended to help immigrants, former welfare recipients and other low-income Americans make poverty a ''stage, not a fate.''

headline.main: Bush Is Proposing a Health Plan to Aid the Needy

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush, campaigning in Cleveland, Ohio, enters national health care policy debate by proposing tax credit of up to $2,000 a family to help low- and moderate-income working people buy health insurance; includes credit, worth $34.7 million over five years, in array of tax incentives and vouchers he offers as $41.6 billion five-year package to help lift low-income Americans out of poverty; Vice Pres Al Gore's campaign holds proposal is aimed at diverting attention from deplorable state of health care in Texas; Bush's aides defend his health care record; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your April 8 editorial ''A Cartel for Doctors,'' referring to the bill proposed by Representative Tom Campbell that would permit doctors to negotiate collectively with health plans as a ''cartel for doctors,'' misses the point. We can no longer be considered independent when all conditions are dictated by health plans. Yes, there is a cartel, but it is the health plans. The bill tries to level the playing field.

headline.main: A Bill for Doctors, and Patients

docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Walter Kahn of New Jersey Medical Society on April 8 editorial opposing bill permitting doctors to negotiate collectively with health plans; says health plans are the 'cartel' (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Texas has had one of the nation's worst public health records for decades. More than a quarter of its residents have no health insurance. Its Mexican border is a hotbed of contagion. The state ranks near the top in the nation in rates of AIDS, diabetes, tuberculosis and teenage pregnancy, and near the bottom in immunizations, mammograms and access to physicians. But since George W. Bush became governor in 1995, he has not made health a priority, his aides acknowledge. He has never made a speech on the subject, his press office says. His administration opposed a patient's bill of rights in 1995 before grudgingly accepting one in 1997, and fought unsuccessfully to limit access to the new federal Children's Health Insurance Program in 1999.

headline.main: Bush and Texas Have Not Set High Priority on Health Care

docs.abstract: Texas has had one of nation's worst public health records for decades, ranking near top in nation's rates of some major diseases and near bottom in terms of prevention; its Mexican border is hotbed of contagion, and more than quarter of its population lacks health insurance; Gov George W Bush, Republican presidential candidate, has not made health priority since taking office in 1995 and has failed to tackle problems despite large state budget surplus; his administration opposed patient's bill of rights in 1995 before grudgingly accepting it in 1997; fought unsuccessfully to limit access to new Children's Health Insurance Program in 1999; health care remains near top of election agenda, and Democrats are already attacking Bush for Texas record, pointing out that state's lack of health insurance is among most severe in country; Vice Pres Al Gore's proposal for vast expansion of insurance coverage for children noted; Texas health officials comment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bitter Partisan Fight Brewing Over Medicare Drug Benefits'' (front page, April 5): While Congress debates the possibility of tossing a few crumbs in the way of prescription coverage to Medicare recipients, they enjoy the best health care coverage in the United States -- most of which is paid for with taxpayers' money.
docs.abstract: Charles Herina Jr letter points out that while Congress considers tossing few crumbs to Medicare recipients who take prescription drugs, lawmakers themselves enjoy best health care coverage in US, paid mostly by taxpayers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re your April 8 editorial ''A Cartel for Doctors,'' opposing Representative Tom Campbell's bill allowing doctors to bargain collectively with health plans: The formidable cartel you fear already exists. It is composed of federal (Medicare) and state (Medicaid) governments and the health insurance industry, which impose de facto price controls on health care providers. With current reimbursements, both doctors and hospitals are barely able to meet the costs of delivering the quality care our society demands.

headline.main: A Bill for Doctors, and Patients

docs.abstract: Dr Robert J Masi letter says medical cartel already exists, composed of federal and state governments and health insurance industry (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Department of Health and Human Services issued a report yesterday that highlighted alarming disparities in prescription drug costs for Medicare beneficiaries. The Medicare recipients who lack drug coverage are charged significantly more -- and are thus forced to do without medicine more often -- than Medicare recipients who have obtained drug coverage one way or another. Currently, about a third of Medicare beneficiaries have no drug coverage at all. The rest have drug coverage through plans provided by former employers, Medigap plans that they buy themselves, Medicaid, or through Medicare health maintenance organizations that provide drug benefits.
docs.abstract: Editorial, commenting on report by Health and Human Services Department highlighting disparities in prescription drug costs for Medicare beneficiaries, says disparities make persuasive case for providing drug benefit for all beneficiaries; says market is working unfairly against those who have no coverage, and that Medicare reform should empower them to use collective purchasing power to get better prices on drugs

docs.lead_paragraph: City dwellers get sick more often than their rural counterparts. Well-educated adults are healthier than those without high school diplomas.

headline.main: Most Likely to Feel Healthy: Educated Rural People

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention release five-year study showing that city dwellers get sick more often than their rural counterparts; finds that well-educated adults are healthier than those without high school educations; finds that people living in poverty are sick most often; in some pockets of high unemployment, residents report feeling unhealthy 20 days a month; for general population, average number of unhealthy days was 5.3; people in South Dakota feel the best, reporting just four unhealthy days a month (M)
docs.snippet: City dwellers get sick more often than their rural counterparts.    Well-educated adults are healthier than those without high school diplomas.
